page.lettertext:
fol.95r
[Feb]
uary
[To m]
y L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. As I writte
in my last
e 10 of this moneth, there was
a Pasport graunted by this
Councel of
Estate
(for suche respectes as I declared
in that letter) to
Mons
r
de Bilandt
Baron of Reide, and one of
e
Emperours
Ambassado
rs
for
e mater of Peace, to come
hither to
e Hage: who is therupon arri-
ved, and hath required Audience of
e
Councel. But having bene heere but
two daies, they have differred it a while.
Heerof, albeit as yet I have no further
mater, I thought it not unfitte to ad-
vertise yo
r
L. upon occasion presented
of a present messenger: as I also purpose
to informe yo
w
, w
t
e first opportunitie,
of whatsoever shall passe in his accesse
unto
e Councel, or shall be pertinent
otherwise to
e cause for w
ch
he comes.
Those troupes that were appointed,
to be sent out of
Holland,
to
e siege of
Rouen,
have bin embarked these 10 daies,
and continewe as yet on shippe borde,
that for want of a winde, and by rea-
son of
e season, w
ch
hath bin heere very
bitter and stormy, it is said they doe sicken
and waxe very weake. The
Councel of State have already sent their
Commissaries, to passe a general muster
of all her
Ma
ties
forces: w
ch
was to be per-
fourmed, as neere as they could before
e
20 of this moneth: and when they are
fol.95v
returned, I will take a Copie of [their rolles]
and certifcats, and send them pres[ently]
to
M
r
Wilkes
. There is n[ews]
heere from
Collen,
that
D. Casimir
,
e
[D. of]
Wirtenbergh
, and
e
Chauncelor of P[oland]
are all deceased of poison: and
at
R[icardus]
great uncle to
e yong
Count Palati[ne]
nephew to Casimir, doth take
e gou[verment]
upon him for 6 monethes, during
e no[nage]
of
e
yong
Prince.
Elector.
This is but [hardly]
heere beleeved, but yet advertised to [divers]
Having no occurrence
of other [mention]
besides
[I take my ]
humble leave.
